summary.topic: welcome to class dmw triple7 or7
summary.summary: welcome to dmw class triple7. let's get started.

summary.topic: let's talk about growth hacking to get the word out
summary.summary: today we'll talk about growth hacking, mainly focusing on strategies to help you 10x your reach. most of you are past the initial zero stage, so this session aims to provide a framework for acquiring more users, followers, or listeners. it's a long session, so i'll speed through it; feel free to stop me with questions.

summary.topic: you have 24 days left; who's feeling confident?
summary.summary: you have 24 days left, how are you feeling? bronson and braden are confident as always. soma feels like they've learned a lot over the past two months, understanding what not to do but still figuring out what to focus on. although not fully on track with their goal, they feel satisfied with their progress and growth.

summary.topic: understanding the process of discovery is important
summary.summary: yeah yeah a lot of this is like riding a bike right now you've got the training wheels on in 24 days they'll come off whether you like it or not but that's okay it's part of the learning process cool but yeah most of you

summary.topic: most of you are too smart for your own good, let's simplify things
summary.summary: you’re too smart for your own good. baby is not B. let's use this next hour to simplify some things, demystify with examples, take your questions, and move forward. the goal is to get out of your head and focus on the essentials.

summary.topic: goal from this talk: get out of your head and get the word out
summary.summary: growth hacking in simple terms is just marketing experiments to acquire new users or retain existing ones. it involves whatever it takes, often including non-traditional methods.

summary.topic: growth hacking is marketing experiments to acquire or retain users
summary.summary: you can approach traditional things as experiments with a hypothesis, quickly proving or disproving them. this applies to anything, like viral videos and marketing. make sense? cool.

summary.topic: can be viral videos, marketing stunts, leveraging other people, ab testing
summary.summary: stunts using others' A/B testing; creating a site. i have a marketing sdu at midnight. anyone got more growth hacks they've tried or heard of? for onboarding, make traditionally boring stuff entertaining and engaging to turn it into a game.

summary.topic: gamification can be a big part of growth hacking
summary.summary: people don't usually participate in something they actually want to join, but if they did, you'd see growth since conversions would rise. gamification plays a big role in this.

summary.topic: leveraging other people's audiences is a growth hack
summary.summary: leveraging podcasts is a growth hack to tap into other people's audiences. josh's videos for you guys are similar, using build space's audience to drive traffic your way. growth hacks can be anything, like paying users for feedback, and today we'll cover various strategies, but remember to quickly test and see what works best for you.

summary.topic: remember: no matter the experiment, goal is to get to a decision fast
summary.summary: doesn't matter what experiment you run, the goal is to get to a decision fast. it's like chemistry: have a hypothesis, quickly carry out the experiment, and get to the results. the decision is whether to double down on the experiment or kill it. don't over complicate.

summary.topic: don't spend weeks on the perfect marketing plan
summary.summary: you have 24 days left, but don't spend 42 weeks on a perfect marketing plan. that might work for big organizations, but not for you. you can't afford the time, and many of you are working alone.

summary.topic: think coding week vs marketing week to balance efforts
summary.summary: week.com is a website that alternates between coding week and marketing week to help people balance their efforts and make better decisions. it's meant for those who keep adding features or working on projects without ever actually finishing or promoting them. the goal is to highlight that getting the word out is just as crucial as the work itself.

summary.topic: it's as important to get the word out as it is to build the product
summary.summary: build the thing you're trying to build and make the most of your time. be crafty with a 'whatever it takes' mentality. that's it.

summary.topic: mentality needed: "whatever it takes"
summary.summary: early slide of kobe bryant: i'll do whatever it takes to win, whether it's sitting on a bench, handing out water, or hitting the game-winning shot. for you, that means doing whatever it takes for your product to succeed, like outreach emails, calling people, or hitting up influencers. try things quickly, see the path to a decision, and decide whether to double down or kill it.

summary.topic: basics of growth hacking: aarrr
summary.summary: yeah, so basically, you know, acquisition, activation, retention, referral, and revenue? you've probably seen this before. it's core marketing stuff. just think of it as a funnel. we'll share the deck later, and you can look at the growth manifesto for more details. for now, focus on acquisition: how are people finding you?

summary.topic: acquisition: how are people finding you?
summary.summary: for music it's spotify, soundcloud, youtube. for software people it's twitter, x, seo ads, reddit, product hunt etc. content creators focus on visibility on tiktok, instagram, youtube shorts, etc. activation is crucial; how long before users say "oh [ __ ]"?

summary.topic: activation: how long before they go "oh [ __ ]"?
summary.summary: basically, it's all about grabbing attention with a product, song, or video. that's the activation point. retention is about people coming back.

summary.topic: retention: are people coming back?
summary.summary: whether it's an email, notification, or text message, the key is whether people are coming back (retention) and telling others about it (referral). push notifications might include emails or viral stunts, while pull is when users habitually seek out information. word of mouth, like sharing experiences or recommending tools, plays a big role in expanding a user base. tracking these metrics helps understand how often people return and if they bring others along.

summary.topic: referral: word of mouth, shares, direct recommendations
summary.summary: using tools and analytics, you can identify which parts of your funnel are effective and which need improvement. finally, revenue is about whether people are actually paying; some may not care about this, but it's like your audience.

summary.topic: revenue: are people paying, tracking a nordstar metric
summary.summary: we're talking about tracking important metrics like nordstar metrics. everyone's tracking different things: followers, subscribers, watch time, users, and revenue. the key is to focus on the entire funnel and run quick experiments to clarify the problems you're solving. it's normal if you're still figuring out the main issues, just iterate and learn.

summary.topic: using a time or money model to clarify messaging
summary.summary: if you're trying to get to the kanye concert from campus, you might compare uber and lyft to see which is cheaper. with one at $44.95 and the other at $35.24, most would pick lyft to save money, assuming quality is similar. but sometimes factors like wait time can make a difference; for instance, waiting 8 minutes for a ride might not be worth saving $12 if the other option arrives in 1 minute. in essence, people choose based on saving time or money, and the same principle applies to optimizing products and services.

summary.topic: transformation model: making the transformation super obvious
summary.summary: people feel misunderstood, and that's why creators like ne's and taylor swift connect with their audiences so deeply—they make them feel heard. when selling a transformation, like better photo quality, focus on how it solves the user's problem directly rather than just showcasing impressive specs. apple does this well by making users believe they can take amazing photos with their devices, creating desire and connection. be straightforward about the transformation you offer without complicating things.

summary.topic: simplifying messages in all forms of communication
summary.summary: make your ads, landing pages, bios, and stories encapsulate the transformation you're selling as simply as possible. for example, when we did nights and weekend season one, we had a large community and we wanted them to feel part of something bigger, like my old school houses system. we created houses to foster a sense of belonging and community similar to the magical feel of sapphire house from my school days.

summary.topic: experiment example: introducing houses in nights and weekends
summary.summary: experimenting quickly, i whipped up four landing pages on framer almost two years ago, using stable diffusion to create simple designs with different fonts. i gathered some team members to pick their favorites, which became the basis for four distinct house identities we subtly introduced over time. now, people have started identifying with these houses, and we're continuing to experiment and plan long-term developments for each house site.

summary.topic: running experiments: quickly testing ideas and learning from them
summary.summary: let it all take its time to marinate properly. we have a lot going on, like people carrying posters around the world. let's keep doubling down on small experiments, use the data, and keep going. moving on to Chronicles of naid from un riddle, is homie here?

summary.topic: growth hacking example: navid and unriddle's influencer tactic
summary.summary: sf1 student building started with 2k mrr and did a ton of growth experiments like creating specific landing pages for different user archetypes, scraping public researcher data for emails, and using outbound marketing tactics. the turning point came when he paid influencers on tiktok to make videos, leading one video to blow up to 600k views, doubling his mrr from 2k to 4k over a weekend. he continued optimizing after gaining traffic and ventured into more experimental phases with influencers and paid ads.

summary.topic: keep trying different things until something works
summary.summary: start tracking data to figure out what's next. essentially, the key takeaway is to run quick, focused experiments to increase traffic and conversions on your site. leverage influencers, optimize your marketing strategies, and tweak pricing options to find what works best. each experiment should be short and provide clear results to either scale the idea or move on. growth hacking is all about trying different tactics rapidly to discover the most effective strategies.

summary.topic: set up data collection to analyze results from experiments
summary.summary: he doesn't have the data in place to know how they're spending their time. before running the next experiment, he wants to make sure that's sorted. going fast is crucial. yesterday, ryan asked how to time box facts. simple rule.

summary.topic: time boxing: use Parkinson's Law to compress work timelines
summary.summary: parkinson's law states that work will expand to fill the time allocated for its completion. if you give a task a long deadline, it'll take that long, even if you could do it faster. combine this with pareto's principle, which suggests that 80% of results come from 20% of efforts, and you'll see how tight deadlines can boost efficiency.

summary.topic: Pareto principle: focus on the 20% of tasks that yield 80% results
summary.summary: use the 80/20 rule to focus on the 20% of tasks that yield 80% of results. for example, spend two days instead of two weeks to update a landing page, allowing 12 extra days to gather data and make improvements. similarly, create content in shorter chunks to quickly gather feedback and optimize effectively.

summary.topic: keeping messaging simple and straightforward
summary.summary: it's more complicated than this, but the idea is to use Parkinson's law and prioritize to figure out your time box and identify the most important tasks. keep things simple for easy understanding and don't overcomplicate like the movie tenet. just keep it straightforward.

summary.topic: examples of creative marketing on platforms like TikTok
summary.summary: check out this account with 150 million views, loads of likes, comments, bookmarks, and shares. it's selling a book titled "don't believe everything you think" with a quick buy option. this is a great example of how tiktok shop is pushing native video products, showing that non-traditional marketing is huge right now—kids with no traditional marketing background are thriving because they start fresh. try out these methods, give it a couple of days, and decide quickly. any questions?

summary.topic: there's no silver bullet; just keep trying new things
summary.summary: actually any questions? was it too much? like too dense? i have a

summary.topic: questions and discussion on applying the frameworks
summary.summary: i was thinking about how a clothing brand can save customers money but that idea doesn't feel satisfying. i want alternatives like saving time, energy, and boosting happiness or status. for example, think about how a Rolex provides status.
